bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, September 5, 1940

div1.p: Hench seeks the source of Truby's information about Lazear's illness. He informs Truby about the upcoming Lazear memorial event.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, September 5, 1940
div1.opener:
September 5, 1940
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
By now you will have received my long memorandum. I
do regret not having written you earlier. As you will note, my letter
was dated some days ago, but was held up by the local photographer, who
couldn't get my pictures done promptly.

I am delighted that both you and General Kean will per-
mit me to use the interesting information about Lazear's illness, and I
thank you most kindly. You say that what you gave me is not second hand.
I should appreciate knowing what you mean by this. Do you mean that
Major Reed told you these facts himself? I am anxious to have this one
point cleared up, about the source of your information.

The date of the Washington and Jefferson College affair
is, I understand, October 26. Washington and Jefferson is a small college
about forty miles from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, but it is the oldest
college west of the Allegheny Mountains. Is there any possibility that you
might be coming East about that time? I am sure the college would be de-
lighted to give you an invitation.

In the meantime, I am anxious to hear your reactions to
my menorandum.
div1.closer: Most sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
